comments:
MATH241 is the fourth and last course in the general calculus sequence. Topics covered include Sturm-Liouville problems, orthogonal functions, Fourier series, partial differential equations (solutions to the heat, wave and Laplace equations), Fourier transformations, and an introduction to complex analysis.

In general, students tended to dislike the class. The course material was “boring” and “too abstract,” and students would like to have seen more real-life applications. While students were introduced to many important topics, the material was “lacking in depth.” One student commented, “Not ONE of my peers is excited about coming to this course,” adding that many “just grind through the course without actually understanding the material.” Another reviewer disliked the textbook, finding it “unclear” and “not very thorough.”

Most students complimented Professor Block for being “engaging,” “intelligent,” “funny,” and “animated” in class. He was said to possess “a gift for explaining difficult concepts” and “warmly invites questions.” One reviewer out of fifteen cautioned that Professor Block was “completely unable to stimulate student interest,” and that his “quick pace” in lecture made it “impossible to follow along.”

MATH240 is a prerequisite for MATH241. Most students taking this class were engineering students, and students majoring in the physical sciences or mathematics. It was said to be “notoriously difficult,” with some greater emphasis placed on the ability to perform algebra quickly rather than on the concepts behind the mathematics.
